How does sea-level pressure differ from station pressure? Can the two ever be the same?

Answer.S: Sea-level pressure is the pressure a station would attain if it were lowered to sea level.  The estimation of what sea level pressure is at each city allows a comparison of pressures at the same elevation which contriols wind flow.
